awd_titl_txt: Natural Curvature and Soft Shells: Shape Shifting through Mechanical Instabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature uses internal stimuli to locally and globally change the curvature of thin and soft materials in a variety of ways. Natural curvatures occur in many biological and engineered structures through differential swelling, heating, or growth. They are: induced by proteins along a cell membrane, critical to the eversion of a developing Volvox embryo, and incurred in residually stressed composite plates and shells. Since natural curvature can drastically affect the morphology of thin bodies and induce mechanical instabilities, this provides a means for creating adaptive, shape-shifting structures capable of growing, morphing, and transitioning between complex shapes. This award supports fundamental research on the mechanics of instabilities induced by a natural curvature within thin shells. Harnessing these concepts for technological applications may enable the design of adaptive metamaterials, soft robotic actuators, and structural materials capable of programmatically controlled shape-shifting. Thus, this project will advance the science associated with mechanical instability; and advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare. This award also supports the further development of the digital inspiration, communication, and education (DICE) program. By placing an emphasis on visual, verbal, and written communication, this program will continue to enhance both the scientific communication of the next generation of scholars and broaden the participation of the general public through the creation and curation of open, online mechanics content.

This research will establish a fundamental understanding of how natural and spontaneous curvatures deform slender structures and soft materials. Its results will help engineer shells that are more robust against buckling, and facilitate the design of shells capable of changing between target shapes on command. The research will establish how natural curvature can provide shells with a knock-up factor against pressure buckling. The research team will utilize experiments that control curvature in soft materials through residual swelling in conjunction with a novel computational model based on a large deformation, rotation-free shell formulation. A fully nonlinear forward and inverse computational shell model to analyze shells with an evolving natural curvature will be developed and validated with experiments. Finally, an understanding of how locally applied natural curvatures deform soft shells will be established, enabling targeted shape-shifting that utilizes the computational modeling to inform the experimental design. This understanding may transform key technologies where shape-shifting materials are being intensely pursued for technological insertion, like soft robotics, deployable structures, and biomimetic design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nature uses internal stimuli to locally and globally change the curvature of thin and soft materials in a variety of ways - a process that generates natural or spontaneous curvature. Lipids induce a global spontaneous curvature in the formation of vesicles, they couple with the cytoskeleton of red blood cells to influence their shape, and they interact with proteins to locally cause curvature changes in the cellular membrane. Differential growth rates in plant stems, branches, and roots induce curvature changes that provide the main mechanism responsible for their gravitropic response, i.e. their ability to redirect their growth direction vertically. Since natural curvatures can drastically affect the shape of thin bodies and induce mechanical instabilities, this provides a means for creating adaptive, shape-shifting structures capable of growing, morphing, and transitioning between complex shapes. Harnessing these concepts for technological applications have been suggested as a means to design adaptive metamaterials and soft robotic actuators. Recent physical insights have established that curvature–induced instabilities in slender structures behave in fundamentally different ways than structures loaded by traditional mechanical forces and pressures. 

The Intellectual Merit for this award centered on the following question: "How does natural curvature deform soft shells, and can we utilize mechanical instabilities triggered by natural curvature to design and create shape-shifting structures?" This award supported the training of three PhD students along with over a half dozen undergraduate researchers. We report on two specific outcomes that we anticipate will have impact well beyond the lifetime of this project.

The first outcome is the development of a novel stimuli-responsive shell theory. We provided both analytical and computational tools for modeling thin, soft structures that are deforming due to, for example, heating, swelling, exposure to electromagnetic fields, and growth. The theory translates these non-mechanical stimuli into effective mechanical forces and moments that act to: (1) stretch, (2) bend, and (3) add/remove mass to the shell. We first demonstrated the validity of this model by using it to explain the morphogenesis of the optic cup, the spherical cavity that forms during embryo development and eventually houses the eyeball. We then demonstrated the theory's ability to model leaf growth, the snapping of the Venus flytrap's leaves, and the buckling of soft, electrically-active polymers in response to an applied voltage.

The second outcome is related to the use of natural curvature to create mechanical metamaterials that have advanced functionality. Metamaterials are materials with properties that do not naturally occur, and mechanical metamaterials achieve these properties by taking advantage of complex, and often multiscale shape and structural changes. With this award, we were able to create a soft robotic gripper by using tools from kirigami - similar to origami, but using cuts rather than folds. The functionality of the soft, "kirigami gripper" was enabled by two features: (1) a specific pattern of cuts; and (2) a change in natural curvature. This resulted in an extremely lightweight structure capable of delicately and precisely grasping a wide variety of objects. What is particularly notable is that the kirigami gripper excels at grasping oddly-shaped, delicate, fragile, and slippery items (Fig. 1). Because the design is based on geometry, it can be scaled up to grasp large objects, or scaled down to grasp an individual grain of sand. Further, multiple grippers can be combined together in series to grasp long, slender objects, and/or in parallel to grasp multiple objects simultaneously. 

Taken together, the results of this award have provided new insights into the growth and development of soft, biological structures, as well as lead to the development of a grasping mechanism capable of handling difficult objects. 

The Broader Impact of this work can be measured in a variety of ways. First, we anticipate these results will impact several disparate academic communities. The kirigami gripper has opened up entrepreneurial opportunities that may one day bring this technology to market. The award supported the development of students coming from diverse backgrounds. Finally, o assist in the broader outreach and dissemination of mechanics, we developed an innovative program to improve scientific communication and literacy by utilizing online digital media to inspire, educate, and communicate science to the broader global community. We developed online videos, notes, and open-source code to inspire curiosity in mechanics, provide learning tools appropriate for a wide range of educational backgrounds, and train students to better communicate science and mechanics.
